intro: Paepalanthus mucronatus, commonly known as the sharp-tipped puya, is a flowering plant native to the high Andes of South America. It belongs to the family Xanthorrhoeaceae and is characterized by its rosette-like growth habit with thick, fleshy leaves. The plant produces a tall flowering stem that bears small, clustered flowers, often in shades of yellow or green. It is adapted to cold, arid environments and is often found in rocky or alpine regions. Due to its unique appearance and habitat, it is considered an important species in ecological studies of high-altitude ecosystems.
